definition: to redress (an injustice)/to rehabilitate (sb whose reputation was unjustly sullied)
flat/level/equal/to tie (make the same score)/to draw (score)/calm/peaceful/see also 平聲|平声[ping2 sheng1]
surname Ping
contrary/in reverse/inside out or upside down/to reverse/to return/to oppose/opposite/against/anti-/to rebel/to use analogy/instead/abbr. for 反切[fan3 qie4] phonetic system

sentences.english: My uncle was thoroughly rehabilitated and given a job.
sentences.chinese: 二舅得到了徹底的平反，有了一份工作。

sentences.english: Till the party 3 in after plenary meeting, just get rehabilitating exonerating .
sentences.chinese: 直到黨的十一屆三中全會後，纔得到平反昭雪。

sentences.english: In 1982, the Organization Ministry of the Central Committee of the CPC announced his rehabilitation.
sentences.chinese: 1982年，中共中央組織部爲張志樂做出平反決定。

sentences.english: They redressed the grievances done to the chief engineer years ago.
sentences.chinese: 他們爲好幾年前總工程師所蒙受的冤屈平反昭雪。

sentences.english: The wronged persons had been righted.
sentences.chinese: 受到冤枉的人們都得到了平反。

sentences.english: However, after Elizabeth became Queen, she cleared her mother's name.
sentences.chinese: 然而，伊莉莎白成爲女王后隨即爲她母親平反。

sentences.english: That explains their rehabilitation in post-Mao China.
sentences.chinese: 所以就有了毛以後中國對企業家的平反。

sentences.english: This reversal has been far less evident in city planning and architecture.
sentences.chinese: 但是這種平反在城市規劃和建築風格上體現甚微。

definition: to exonerate/to clear (from an accusation)/to rehabilitate
to reverse a verdict/to present different views on a historical person or verdict
to be wronged/to be subjected to an injustice
miscarriage of justice
to grant a special pardon
restored to one's official post/to send sb back to his former post
to rehabilitate/to regain one's good name
wronged/to suffer false accusations
unjust charge or verdict/miscarriage of justice/frame-up
to resume a post
to receive unjust treatment/injustice
lit. to wash out a grievance/fig. to right a wrong/to redress an injustice
to appeal for justice/to demand redress for a grievance
to expose/to bring to light/to disclose/revelation
to right wrongs/to redress an injustice
to complain bitterly
